title: Lalita Niwas Land Grab Scam
description:
The Lalita Niwas land grab is a major corruption scandal in Nepal involving the illegal privatization of approximately 143 ropanis of government-owned land in Baluwatar, Kathmandu. This land is part of a larger complex that houses the Prime Minister's official residence and the Nepal Rastra Bank's central office. The land was originally acquired by the government in 1961 under the Land Acquisition Act after providing compensation to its owner, Subarna Shamsher Rana.

The scam was orchestrated over several decades, reportedly between 1992 and 2012, through a conspiracy involving land revenue officials, brokers, businesspersons, and high-level political figures. The perpetrators allegedly forged government documents and manipulated cabinet-level policy decisions to transfer the state-owned land to private individuals and business groups.

Key phases of the scam include:

  • 1992: Officials at the Dillibazar Land Revenue Office illegally transferred 113 ropanis of government-acquired land back to private individuals, allegedly misinterpreting a 1990 cabinet decision intended to return land seized by the former Panchayat regime.
  • 2010: The cabinet led by Prime Minister Madhav Kumar Nepal, with Vijay Kumar Gachhadar as Minister for Physical Infrastructure, made decisions to expand the Prime Minister's residence. These decisions involved compensating individuals who had illegally occupied parts of the Lalita Niwas land, thereby legitimizing their fraudulent claims.
  • 2012: The cabinet led by Prime Minister Baburam Bhattarai gave approval to register government land from the complex under the name of a non-existent entity, the 'Pashupati Tikinchha Guthi'.

Investigations by the Commission for the Investigation of Abuse of Authority (CIAA) and the Central Investigation Bureau (CIB) of Nepal Police followed a probe committee report led by former secretary Sharada Prasad Trital. The CIAA filed a corruption case against 175 individuals in 2020, and the District Attorney's Office filed a separate forgery case against 310 individuals in 2023. The case has seen arrests of prominent figures, investigations into former Prime Ministers, and a partial acquittal of four former ministers by the Special Court in February 2024.
unverified_info:
The following information is from news reports and public discourse but has not been definitively confirmed by official investigation or court records:

  • Some members of the Madhav Kumar Nepal-led cabinet have reportedly claimed that the proposals concerning Lalita Niwas were never formally discussed during meetings, suggesting the decision might have been pushed through by the Prime Minister without full cabinet deliberation.
  • The Commission for the Investigation of Abuse of Authority (CIAA) chose not to indict then-NCP General Secretary Bishnu Prasad Paudel and Supreme Court Justice Kumar Regmi, who had purchased plots of the land. The CIAA's reasoning was that they had pledged to return the illegally acquired property to the state.
  • The exact origin of the name 'Lalita Niwas' is a matter of historical anecdote, widely believed to be named after the mother of Subarna Shamsher Rana, but this is not officially documented in the case files.
key_allegations: Illegal transfer and privatization of 143 ropanis of government-owned land.
Forgery of government documents and creation of fake land tenants to claim ownership.
Manipulation of cabinet-level policy decisions to legitimize fraudulent land claims.
Collusion between high-level politicians, government officials, land brokers, and businesspersons.
Creation of a non-existent 'Guthi' (trust) to facilitate the illegal transfer of land.
Causing financial loss to the state amounting to billions of Nepali Rupees.
related_entities: Commission for the Investigation of Abuse of Authority (CIAA)

timeline.title: Illegal Land Transfer Begins
timeline.description: Officials at the Dillibazar Land Revenue Office allegedly misinterpret a 1990 cabinet decision and illegally transfer 113 ropanis and 3 annas of government-acquired land back to private individuals. This marks the beginning of the embezzlement period.

timeline.title: Cabinet Decision Legitimizes Illegal Claims
timeline.description: The Madhav Kumar Nepal-led cabinet decides to expand the Prime Minister's residence, a move which involved compensating individuals illegally holding parts of Lalita Niwas land, thereby regularizing their fraudulent ownership.

timeline.title: Cabinet Approves Transfer to Fake Guthi
timeline.description: The Baburam Bhattarai-led cabinet gives in-principle approval to register government land from the complex in the name of a non-existent entity called the 'Pashupati Tikinchha Guthi'.

timeline.title: Government Forms Trital Probe Committee
timeline.description: The government forms an investigation committee headed by former Secretary Sharada Prasad Trital to probe irregularities concerning the Lalita Niwas land.

timeline.title: Trital Committee Submits Report
timeline.description: The Sharada Prasad Trital-led committee submits its detailed report to the government, outlining the decades-long conspiracy.

timeline.title: CIAA Files Corruption Case
timeline.description: The CIAA files a corruption case at the Special Court against 175 individuals, including former DPM Vijay Kumar Gachhadar and three other former ministers. Former PMs were exempted.

timeline.title: CIB Begins Arresting Suspects
timeline.description: The Central Investigation Bureau (CIB) begins arresting key suspects, including Bhatbhateni owner Min Bahadur Gurung and former secretary Sudhir Shah.

timeline.title: Supreme Court Orders Investigation of Former PMs
timeline.description: The Supreme Court issues a directive to investigate policy-level decision-makers involved in the scam, specifically naming former Prime Ministers Madhav Kumar Nepal and Baburam Bhattarai.

timeline.title: CIB Records Statements from Former PMs
timeline.description: Following the Supreme Court order, the CIB records statements from former Prime Ministers Madhav Kumar Nepal and Baburam Bhattarai regarding their cabinets' decisions.

timeline.title: Forgery Case Filed Against 310 Individuals
timeline.description: The District Attorney's Office in Kathmandu files a separate case for forgery against 310 individuals, including government officials, land brokers, and beneficiaries.

timeline.title: Court Orders Release of Suspects on Bail
timeline.description: The Kathmandu District Court orders the release of all 18 individuals who had been arrested by the CIB on bail.

timeline.title: Special Court Acquits Four Former Ministers
timeline.description: The Special Court acquits former ministers Vijay Kumar Gachhadar, Sanjay Kumar Shah, Dambar Bahadur Shrestha, and Chandradev Joshi in the corruption case filed by the CIAA.
